content.text: DSA Counting Sort with Python
Counting Sort
The Counting Sort algorithm sorts an array by counting the number of times each value occurs.
content.html: The Counting Sort algorithm sorts an array by counting the number of times each value occurs.

content.text: Run the simulation to see how 17 integer values from 1 till 5 are sorted using Counting Sort.
content.html: Run the simulation to see how 17 integer values from 1 till 5 are sorted using Counting Sort.

content.text: Counting Sort does not compare values like the previous sorting algorithms we have looked at, and only works on non negative integers.
content.html: Counting Sort does not compare values like the previous sorting algorithms we have looked at, and only works on non negative integers.

content.text: Furthermore, Counting Sort is fast when the range of possible values k k is smaller than the number of values n n .
content.html: Furthermore, Counting Sort is fast when the range of possible values kk is smaller than the number of values nn.

content.text: How it works:
content.html: How it works:

content.text: Conditions for Counting Sort
These are the reasons why Counting Sort is said to only work for a limited range of non-negative integer values:
content.html: These are the reasons why Counting Sort is said to only work for a limited range of non-negative integer values:

content.text: Manual Run Through
Before we implement the Counting Sort algorithm in a programming language, let's manually run through a short array, just to get the idea.
content.html: Before we implement the Counting Sort algorithm in a programming language, let's manually run through a short array, just to get the idea.

content.text: Step 1: We start with an unsorted array.
content.html: Step 1: We start with an unsorted array.

content.text: Step 2: We create another array for counting how many there are of each value. The array has 4 elements, to hold values 0 through 3.
content.html: Step 2: We create another array for counting how many there are of each value. The array has 4 elements, to hold values 0 through 3.

content.code_html:
myArray = [ 2, 3, 0, 2, 3, 2]
countArray = [ 0, 0, 0, 0]

content.text: Step 3: Now let's start counting. The first element is 2, so we must increment the counting array element at index 2.
content.html: Step 3: Now let's start counting. The first element is 2, so we must increment the counting array element at index 2.

content.code_html:
myArray = [ 2, 3, 0, 2, 3, 2]
countArray = [ 0, 0, 1, 0]

content.text: Step 4: After counting a value, we can remove it, and count the next value, which is 3.
content.html: Step 4: After counting a value, we can remove it, and count the next value, which is 3.

content.code_html:
myArray = [ 3, 0, 2, 3, 2]
countArray = [ 0, 0, 1, 1]

content.text: Step 5: The next value we count is 0, so we increment index 0 in the counting array.
content.html: Step 5: The next value we count is 0, so we increment index 0 in the counting array.

content.code_html:
myArray = [ 0, 2, 3, 2]
countArray = [ 1, 0, 1, 1]

content.text: Step 6: We continue like this until all values are counted.
content.html: Step 6: We continue like this until all values are counted.

content.code_html:
myArray = [ ]
countArray = [ 1, 0, 3, 2]

content.text: Step 7: Now we will recreate the elements from the initial array, and we will do it so that the elements are ordered lowest to highest.
content.html: Step 7: Now we will recreate the elements from the initial array, and we will do it so that the elements are ordered lowest to highest.

content.text: The first element in the counting array tells us that we have 1 element with value 0. So we push 1 element with value 0 into the array, and we decrease the element at index 0 in the counting array with 1.
content.html: The first element in the counting array tells us that we have 1 element with value 0. So we push 1 element with value 0 into the array, and we decrease the element at index 0 in the counting array with 1.

content.code_html:
myArray = [ 0]
countArray = [ 0, 0, 3, 2]

content.text: Step 8: From the counting array we see that we do not need to create any elements with value 1.
content.html: Step 8: From the counting array we see that we do not need to create any elements with value 1.

content.code_html:
myArray = [ 0]
countArray = [ 0, 0, 3, 2]

content.text: Step 9: We push 3 elements with value 2 into the end of the array. And as we create these elements we also decrease the counting array at index 2.
content.html: Step 9: We push 3 elements with value 2 into the end of the array. And as we create these elements we also decrease the counting array at index 2.

content.code_html:
myArray = [ 0, 2, 2, 2]
countArray = [ 0, 0, 0, 2]

content.text: Step 10: At last we must add 2 elements with value 3 at the end of the array.
content.html: Step 10: At last we must add 2 elements with value 3 at the end of the array.

content.code_html:
myArray = [0, 2, 2, 2, 3, 3]
countArray = [ 0, 0, 0, 0]

content.text: Finally! The array is sorted.
content.html: Finally! The array is sorted.

content.text: Run the simulation below to see the steps above animated:
content.html: Run the simulation below to see the steps above animated:

content.text: Implement Counting Sort in Python
To implement the Counting Sort algorithm in a Python program, we need:
content.html: To implement the Counting Sort algorithm in a Python program, we need:

content.text: One more thing: We need to find out what the highest value in the array is, so that the counting array can be created with the correct size. For example, if the highest value is 5, the counting array must be 6 elements in total, to be able count all possible non negative integers 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5.
content.html: One more thing: We need to find out what the highest value in the array is, so that the counting array can be created with the correct size. For example, if the highest value is 5, the counting array must be 6 elements in total, to be able count all possible non negative integers 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5.

content.text: The resulting code looks like this:
content.html: The resulting code looks like this:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
def countingSort(arr):
  max_val = max(arr)
  count = [0] * (max_val + 1)

  while len(arr) > 0:
    num = arr.pop(0)
    count[num] += 1

  for i in range(len(count)):
    while count[i] > 0:
      arr.append(i)
      count[i] -= 1

  return arr

mylist = [4, 2, 2, 6, 3, 3, 1, 6, 5, 2, 3]
mysortedlist = countingSort(mylist)

print(mysortedlist)

content.code:
def countingSort(arr):
max_val = max(arr)
count = [0] * (max_val + 1)

while len(arr) > 0:
num = arr.pop(0)
count[num] += 1

for i in range(len(count)):
while count[i] > 0:
arr.append(i)
count[i] -= 1

return arr

mylist = [4, 2, 2, 6, 3, 3, 1, 6, 5, 2, 3]
mysortedlist = countingSort(mylist)
print(mysortedlist)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
def countingSort(arr):
  max_val = max(arr)
  count = [0] * (max_val + 1)

  while len(arr) > 0:
    num = arr.pop(0)
    count[num] += 1

  for i in range(len(count)):
    while count[i] > 0:
      arr.append(i)
      count[i] -= 1

  return arr

mylist = [4, 2, 2, 6, 3, 3, 1, 6, 5, 2, 3]
mysortedlist = countingSort(mylist)

print(mysortedlist)

content.text: Counting Sort Time Complexity
How fast the Counting Sort algorithm runs depends on both the range of possible values k k and the number of values n n .
content.html: How fast the Counting Sort algorithm runs depends on both the range of possible values kk and the number of values nn.

content.text: In general, time complexity for Counting Sort is O ( n + k ) O ( n + k ) .
content.html: In general, time complexity for Counting Sort is O(n+k)O(n+k).

content.text: In a best case scenario, the range of possible different values k k is very small compared to the number of values n n and Counting Sort has time complexity O ( n ) O ( n ) .
content.html: In a best case scenario, the range of possible different values kk is very small compared to the number of values nn and Counting Sort has time complexity O(n)O(n).

content.text: But in a worst case scenario, the range of possible different values k k is very big compared to the number of values n n and Counting Sort can have time complexity O ( n 2 ) O ( n 2 ) or even worse.
content.html: But in a worst case scenario, the range of possible different values kk is very big compared to the number of values nn and Counting Sort can have time complexity O(n2)O(n2) or even worse.

content.text: The plot below shows how much the time complexity for Counting Sort can vary.
content.html: The plot below shows how much the time complexity for Counting Sort can vary.

content.text: As you can see, it is important to consider the range of values compared to the number of values to be sorted before choosing Counting Sort as your algorithm. Also, as mentioned at the top of the page, keep in mind that Counting Sort only works for non negative integer values.
content.html: As you can see, it is important to consider the range of values compared to the number of values to be sorted before choosing Counting Sort as your algorithm. Also, as mentioned at the top of the page, keep in mind that Counting Sort only works for non negative integer values.

content.text: As mentioned previously: if the numbers to be sorted varies a lot in value (large k k ), and there are few numbers to sort (small n n ), the Counting Sort algorithm is not effective.
content.html: As mentioned previously: if the numbers to be sorted varies a lot in value (large kk), and there are few numbers to sort (small nn), the Counting Sort algorithm is not effective.

content.text: If we hold n n and k k fixed, the "Random", "Descending" and "Ascending" alternatives in the simulation above results in the same number of operations. This is because the same thing happens in all three cases: A counting array is set up, the numbers are counted, and the new sorted array is created.
content.html: If we hold nn and kk fixed, the "Random", "Descending" and "Ascending" alternatives in the simulation above results in the same number of operations. This is because the same thing happens in all three cases: A counting array is set up, the numbers are counted, and the new sorted array is created.
